awd_titl_txt: CAREER: Synthetically Controlled Plasmon-Multiexciton Interaction in Semiconductor-Metal Hybrid Nanostructures
awd_abstract_narration:
The Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN) Program in the Division of Chemistry at the NSF is funding Professor Jing Zhao of the University of Connecticut (UCONN) to develop synthetic methods to improve the emitting properties of nanostructures based on metallic and semi-conductor nanoparticles for applications in lasers.  When excited by light, nanosized metal and semiconductor crystals exhibit unique optical properties. By combining these two types of particles in one hybrid structure, increased light emission is expected. The hybrid nanomaterials can potentially be used in nanolasers and as the photon source in communication systems. New courses are being developed for undergraduate and graduate students focusing on optical nanomaterials and their applications in many different technologies.  The research is also being integrated into outreach activities for high school students participating in a UCONN chemistry summer workshop, where the synthesis and optical characterization of metal and semiconductor nanocrystals are being undertaken. 

In this research, a novel synthetic method is being developed to fabricate a one-to-one metal-semiconductor hybrid nanostructure with control of its spatial relationship.  Geometric and optical factors that modulate the plasmon-exciton interaction in the hybrid nanostructures are identified so that the hybrid materials can be effectively designed and fabricated for desired applications. A correlated structure-property approach at the single particle level is used to understand how the geometry of the nanostructures determines their plasmon resonance and exciton/multiexciton emission efficiencies. This work focuses on the plasmonic effect on the multiexciton emission efficiency of single semiconductor nanocrystals and its dependence on interparticle distance, excitation conditions and geometry of the nanostructures.  The research includes: (i) producing new synthetic strategies to fabricate one-to-one, metal-semiconductor hybrid nanostructures; (ii) revealing the relationship between the geometry of the hybrid nanoparticles and their optical properties at a single particle level; and (iii) elucidating the plasmon enhancement mechanism of the multiexciton emission efficiency of single semiconductor nanocrystals. The knowledge and nanomaterials obtained from the research is applied in the design and fabrication of optoelectronic devices to improve their performance.  In collaboration with the UCONN Early College Experience program, short courses and laboratory demonstrations for high school teachers and students are also being developed. Moreover, female and underrepresented minorities are encouraged to participate in the research program.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
The main outcomes of this award are: 

1. We reported wavelength-dependent emission of biexcitons in single quantum dots (QDs) deposited on Au nanoparticles. The emission of the biexciton was stronger than that of the exciton when the QDs were excited near the localized surface plasmon resonance of Au nanoparticles, changing the photons emitted from "anti-bunched" to "bunched". The findings demonstrated that the photon statistics of single QDs near plasmonic nanostructures can be modulated by excitation wavelengths.

2. We observed strongly coupled modes between the multipolar plasmon modes of Au nanoparticle dimers and excitons of CdSe/CdS core/shell QDs when QDs were sandwiched between Au nanoparticles. The coupled "plexitonic" modes were shown as dips in both the scattering spectra of Au dimers and the fluorescence spectra of QDs. The strength of the coupling was governed by the size of the QDs and Au nanoparticles, and also the interparticle distance.

3. We investigated whether the photoluminescence lifetime of QDs would change depending on excitation wavelength when the QDs were placed near Au nanoparticles. Traditionally, the photoluminescence lifetime of QDs or fluorophores in general is independent of excitation wavelength, known as Kasha's rule. However, when the QDs are placed near Au nanoparticles, we observed slight changes in their photoluminescence decays at both the ensemble and single QD level. By comparing the ratios of the photoluminescence intensity and lifetimes of the same QD excited at different wavelengths, we determined that the single exciton lifetime of the QDs remained the same with mathematical rigor. The shortening in photoluminescence lifetime of QDs on plasmonic substrate when they were excited "on" plasmon resonance was attributed to the higher portion of multiexciton emission compared to when they were excited "off" resonance.

4. We developed several protocols to produce metal and semiconductor nanostructures and studied the mechanisms that affect the morphology of the nanostructures. They include i) growing silica domains on Au nanoparticles in a controlled manner; ii) fabricating Au nanoparticle-QDs-Au nanoparticle sandwiched structures with tunable sizes of QDs and Au nanoparticles via colloidal assembly; iii) synthesizing tetrapod-shaped CdSe/CdS quantum dots with asymmetric arms.

5. The results from the award have been dissentimated to the publication via peer-reviewed publication, oral and poster presentations at academic conferences and departmental seminars. 26 peer-reviewed publications were published that acknowledged this grant. 

6.In terms of human resources development, during the grant period, PI Zhao was promoted to associate professor with tenure in 2018. Seven graduate students involved in the projects supported by the grant were awarded PhD degrees. Four of them are currently working in industry, three in academia.

7. A special topics class named "Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN)" were offered three times to both graduate and undergraduate students. The class has both a lecture component and a hands-on laboratory component. The students in the class learned the basic concepts and lasted development in the area of MSN. During the pandemic of covid-19, the nanochemistry lab was turned into a virtual lab development, where the students were divided into two groups and developed two online lab modules on Au nanoparticle and CdSe QD synthesis.

 


Last Modified: 05/18/2023
Modified by: Jing Zhao
por.por_txt_cntn:
The main outcomes of this award are: 

1. We reported wavelength-dependent emission of biexcitons in single quantum dots (QDs) deposited on Au nanoparticles. The emission of the biexciton was stronger than that of the exciton when the QDs were excited near the localized surface plasmon resonance of Au nanoparticles, changing the photons emitted from "anti-bunched" to "bunched". The findings demonstrated that the photon statistics of single QDs near plasmonic nanostructures can be modulated by excitation wavelengths.

2. We observed strongly coupled modes between the multipolar plasmon modes of Au nanoparticle dimers and excitons of CdSe/CdS core/shell QDs when QDs were sandwiched between Au nanoparticles. The coupled "plexitonic" modes were shown as dips in both the scattering spectra of Au dimers and the fluorescence spectra of QDs. The strength of the coupling was governed by the size of the QDs and Au nanoparticles, and also the interparticle distance.

3. We investigated whether the photoluminescence lifetime of QDs would change depending on excitation wavelength when the QDs were placed near Au nanoparticles. Traditionally, the photoluminescence lifetime of QDs or fluorophores in general is independent of excitation wavelength, known as Kasha's rule. However, when the QDs are placed near Au nanoparticles, we observed slight changes in their photoluminescence decays at both the ensemble and single QD level. By comparing the ratios of the photoluminescence intensity and lifetimes of the same QD excited at different wavelengths, we determined that the single exciton lifetime of the QDs remained the same with mathematical rigor. 4. We developed several protocols to produce metal and semiconductor nanostructures and studied the mechanisms that affect the morphology of the nanostructures. They include i) growing silica domains on Au nanoparticles in a controlled manner; ii) fabricating Au nanoparticle-QDs-Au nanoparticle sandwiched structures with tunable sizes of QDs and Au nanoparticles via colloidal assembly; iii) synthesizing tetrapod-shaped CdSe/CdS quantum dots with asymmetric arms.

5. The results from the award have been dissentimated to the publication via peer-reviewed publication, oral and poster presentations at academic conferences and departmental seminars. 26 peer-reviewed publications were published that acknowledged this grant. 

6.In terms of human resources development, during the grant period, PI Zhao was promoted to associate professor with tenure in 2018. Seven graduate students involved in the projects supported by the grant were awarded PhD degrees. Four of them are currently working in industry, three in academia.

7. A special topics class named "Macromolecular, Supramolecular, and Nanochemistry (MSN)" were offered three times to both graduate and undergraduate students. The class has both a lecture component and a hands-on laboratory component. The students in the class learned the basic concepts and lasted development in the area of MSN. During the pandemic of covid-19, the nanochemistry lab was turned into a virtual lab development, where the students were divided into two groups and developed two online lab modules on Au nanoparticle and CdSe QD synthesis.
